That sounds like an interesting project, but I don't have any knowledge or suggestions about the topic, other than one experience: I applied at an AI company that dealt with semantics, and the manager told me a story about how their company received a question about whether the company's AI software could read a certain type of file that the requester's group used, so the company took a look at the requester's data file. Although the software the company used was believed to be able to automatically figure out the structure of any data file, it failed on this one particular file, even with human aid. That problem has fascinated me ever since, because it suggested that determining the structure of a data file is a very difficult problem to solve in a general way. I assume that principle also applies to web pages. As applied to your project, this *might* mean that such software does not exist, depending on the complexity of the web page.

It's not a matter of "capabilities." It's more a matter of designing stuff takes lots of time and effort. I'm not talking about the actual drawing or editing process, though even that is non trivial with AI. It's more in the figuring out what needs to be drawn or edited. It's really difficult to come up with something that moves people, the most AI can do is move the bar for what people consider the bare minimum.It takes a level of understanding of what "video editing" or "graphical design" actually entails, which is not what most people want. What most people really want is for someone to understand their vision from a few scraps and tidbits, and then do a lot of other stuff that aligns with that vision. AI is great at the exact opposite; you give it a lot of data, and it'll give you something that satisfies most of those criteria. For someone familiar with a field this is great, because it can save you something like 80% of the work. The remaining 20% may be the most difficult stuff, but it's a lot easier if you don't have to do the first 80% beforehand.But you're right in one sense; the cost of those services should probably include the cost of the OpenAI subscription, as well as the many other AI's that you need to do the services being discussed these days.

Visually, AI is capable of dreaming up new worlds, taking us places we've never been before. Artists like Thierry Lechanteur are using it to create exciting, imaginative, otherworldly outputs. Why aren't we seeing a similar level of creativity in the text-based outputs being created by AI?

I think language models are commonly used pretty creatively. I've heard of people using them for creative writing purposes. They are definitely commonly used for text adventures, such as a DM, and for ERP. Due to the nature of the underlying self-attention layers of language models, I'd imagine it's quite difficult for them to produce very long strands of text that tie together in meaningful ways other than a name being recurring throughout a story - but perhaps that can be improved upon in the future.

I wouldn't say AI is "capable of dreaming up new worlds". It's a user that has dreamed up the world and asked AI to generate what they're thinking of. AI is producing a visualization of a humans request.I would say the difference is people are able to look at the picture and it takes a minute to notice the sixth finger or whatever else is wrong. The more abstract the easier it is to forgive weirdness in the picture, whereas with language if there's a grammatically weird statement in each sentence you're going to notice a lot quicker.
It is very hard for humans to exactly put into words what we have in mind. The AI gives us exactly what we asked for, nothing less and nothing more, and that is usually disappointing.
AI can only mix existing worlds that it has access to in its training. So far there isn't a way to hallucinate into something coherent that could amount to a 'new' anything.
Sure but Thierry Lechenteur is not an artist.
